title: Getting Started with gtregression
text: gtregression package provides user-friendly interface generating publication-ready regression tables, performing model diagnostics, visualizing results, identifying confounders. especially designed beginner analysts, epidemiologists, public health professionals—particularly low- middle-income country (LMIC) settings—promote use open-access tools data analytics. vignette demonstrates use key functions package.

title: Getting Started with gtregression
text: development gtregression driven need make R approachable find intimidating overly technical. many public health professionals, researchers, students LMICs, regression modeling R can feel fragmented difficult interpret. intentionally rely existing, well-tested packages — can’t code , ’s better users stand stable ground. job smooth path : Wrapping complexity clear function calls Minimising required parameters smart defaults Offering layered outputs: readable summary + full technical object Reducing time--insight time--publish justifying dependencies tools serve user, maintain transparency staying focused enhancing experience.
code: library(gtregression) library(dplyr)

title: Getting Started with gtregression
text: use PimaIndiansDiabetes2 dataset:
code: data("PimaIndiansDiabetes2", package = "gtregression")  pima_data <- PimaIndiansDiabetes2 %>%   mutate(diabetes = ifelse(diabetes == "pos", 1, 0)) %>%   mutate(     bmi = case_when(mass < 25 ~ "Normal",                     mass >= 25 & mass < 30 ~ "Overweight",                     mass >= 30 ~ "Obese"),     bmi = factor(bmi, levels = c("Normal", "Overweight", "Obese")),     age_cat = case_when(age < 30 ~ "Young",                         age >= 30 & age < 50 ~ "Middle-aged",                         age >= 50 ~ "Older"),     age_cat = factor(age_cat, levels = c("Young", "Middle-aged", "Older"))   )

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: uni_tbl <- uni_reg(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi", "age_cat"),   approach = "logit" )  uni_tbl  multi_tbl <- multi_reg(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi", "age_cat"),   approach = "logit" )  multi_tbl

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: stratified_uni <- stratified_uni_reg(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi"),   stratifier = "age_cat",   approach = "logit" ) stratified_uni  stratified_multi <- stratified_multi_reg(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi"),   stratifier = "age_cat",   approach = "logit" )  stratified_multi

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: identify_confounder(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposure = "bmi",   potential_confounder = "age_cat",   approach = "logit" )

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: check_convergence(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi", "age_cat"),   approach = "logit" )

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: model_selection <- select_models(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposures = c("bmi", "age_cat"),   approach = "logit",   direction = "forward" )  model_selection$results_table model_selection$best_model

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: interaction_models(   data = pima_data,   outcome = "diabetes",   exposure = "bmi",   covariates = "age_cat",   effect_modifier = "glucose_cat",   approach = "logit",   test = "LRT" )

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: plot_reg(uni_tbl)  plot_reg(multi_tbl)  plot_reg_combine(   tbl_uni = uni_tbl,   tbl_multi = multi_tbl,   title_uni = "Unadjusted",   title_multi = "Adjusted" )

title: Getting Started with gtregression
code: save_table(multi_tbl, file = "regression_table.html")     save_docx(multi_tbl, file = "regression_table.docx")     save_plot(plot_reg(multi_tbl), file = "regression_plot.png")

title: Getting Started with gtregression
text: gtregression package simplifies regression coding produces publication-ready tables interpretation notes. enables beginners explore variety regression models ease, transparency, reproducibility. Explore documentation function discover additional options customization features.

what: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
title: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
text: Computes Variance Inflation Factors (VIF) fitted models returned uni_reg(), multi_reg(), uni_reg_nbin(), multi_reg_nbin(). Returns one VIF table per model. multivariate models

title: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
code: check_collinearity(model)

title: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
text: model fitted model object class "uni_reg", "multi_reg", "uni_reg_nbin", "multi_reg_nbin".

title: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
text: tibble containing VIF values interpretation. multivariable models, returns one tibble. univariate models, error raised indicating VIF applicable.

title: Check Collinearity Using VIF for Fitted Models — check_collinearity
code: if (requireNamespace("gtregression", quietly = TRUE) &&   requireNamespace("mlbench", quietly = TRUE) &&   getRversion() >= "4.1.0") {   data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench")   pima <- PimaIndiansDiabetes2 |> dplyr::filter(!is.na(diabetes))   pima$diabetes <- ifelse(pima$diabetes == "pos", 1, 0)   fit <- multi_reg(pima,     outcome = "diabetes",     exposures = c("age", "mass", "glucose"),     approach = "logit"   )   check_collinearity(fit) } #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   Variable   VIF Interpretation  #>   <chr>    <dbl> <chr>           #> 1 age       1.04 No collinearity #> 2 mass      1.02 No collinearity #> 3 glucose   1.02 No collinearity

what: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
text: Assesses model convergence provides diagnostics exposure (univariate mode) full model (multivariable mode), depending regression approach used.

title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
code: check_convergence(   data,   exposures,   outcome,   approach = "logit",   multivariate = FALSE )

title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
text: data data frame containing dataset. exposures character vector predictor variable names. multivariate = FALSE, exposure assessed separately; otherwise, combined model evaluated. outcome character string specifying outcome variable. approach character string specifying regression approach. One :   "logit", "log-binomial", "poisson",   "robpoisson", "negbin". multivariate Logical. TRUE, checks convergence multivariable model;   otherwise, performs checks univariate model.

title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
text: data frame summarizing convergence diagnostics, including: Exposure Name exposure variable. Model regression approach used. Converged TRUE model converged successfully;    FALSE otherwise. Max.prob Maximum predicted probability   fitted value dataset.

title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
text: robpoisson, predicted probabilities (fitted values) may exceed 1, acceptable estimating risk ratios interpreted actual probabilities. function useful identifying convergence issues, especially "log-binomial" models, often fail converge .

title: Check Convergence for a Regression Model — check_convergence
code: if (requireNamespace("gtregression", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(data_PimaIndiansDiabetes, package = "gtregression")    check_convergence(     data = data_PimaIndiansDiabetes,     exposures = c("age", "bmi"),     outcome = "diabetes",     approach = "logit"   )    check_convergence(     data = data_PimaIndiansDiabetes,     exposures = c("age", "bmi"),     outcome = "diabetes",     approach = "logit",     multivariate = TRUE   ) } #>               Exposure Model Converged Max.prob. #> multivariable       NA logit     FALSE        NA

title: Birth Weight Data — data_birthwt
text: dataset MASS package containing risk factors associated low birth weight (LBW) newborns. Originally collected Baystate Medical Center, Springfield, Massachusetts, USA.

title: Birth Weight Data — data_birthwt
code: data_birthwt

title: Birth Weight Data — data_birthwt
text: data frame 189 observations 10 variables: low Indicator birth weight < 2500g (binary):   0 = normal, 1 = low birth weight age Mother's age years (numeric) lwt Mother's weight pounds last menstrual period (numeric) race Mother's race (factor): 1 = White, 2 = Black,   3 = smoke Smoking status pregnancy (binary): 0 = ,    1 = Yes ptl Number previous premature labors (integer) ht History hypertension (binary): 0 = , 1 = Yes ui Presence uterine irritability (binary): 0 = ,   1 = Yes ftv physician visits 1st trimester (integer, 0–6) bwt Birth weight grams (numeric)

title: Birth Weight Data — data_birthwt
text: Hosmer, D.W., Lemeshow, S. (1989). *Applied Logistic Regression.* New York: Wiley. Also available MASS described detail documentation.

title: Birth Weight Data — data_birthwt
text: outcome variable binary (`low`): birth weight < 2500g (yes = 1) (= 0).

title: PimaIndians2 Diabetes Dataset — data_PimaIndiansDiabetes

code: data_PimaIndiansDiabetes

title: PimaIndians2 Diabetes Dataset — data_PimaIndiansDiabetes
text: data frame 768 observations 9 variables: pregnant Number times pregnant glucose Plasma glucose concentration (glucose tolerance test) pressure Diastolic blood pressure (mm Hg) triceps Triceps skin fold thickness (mm) insulin 2-Hour serum insulin (mu U/ml) mass Body mass index (BMI) pedigree Diabetes pedigree function age Age years diabetes Factor indicating diabetes status (pos/neg)

title: PimaIndians2 Diabetes Dataset — data_PimaIndiansDiabetes
text: https://www.openml.org/d/37

title: Fit Multivariable Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model
text: Fits regression model based selected approach multiple exposures.

title: Fit Multivariable Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model
code: .fit_multi_model(data, outcome, exposures, approach)

title: Fit Multivariable Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model
text: data `data.frame` complete observations outcome exposures. outcome string. Name outcome variable. exposures character vector predictor (exposure) variable names. approach string specifying regression approach. One `"logit"`, `"log-binomial"`, `"poisson"`, `"linear"`, `"robpoisson"`.

title: Fit Multivariable Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model
text: fitted model object (`glm`, `lm`, `riskratio`) `NULL` fitting fails.

title: Fit Multivariable Negative Binomial Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model_nbin
text: Fits negative binomial regression using `glm.nb()` count outcome multiple predictors.

title: Fit Multivariable Negative Binomial Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model_nbin
code: .fit_multi_model_nbin(data, outcome, exposures)

title: Fit Multivariable Negative Binomial Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model_nbin
text: data `data.frame` complete observations outcome exposures. outcome string. Name count outcome variable. exposures character vector predictor (exposure) variable names.

title: Fit Multivariable Negative Binomial Model (Internal) — .fit_multi_model_nbin
text: fitted model object (class `negbin`) `NULL` model fitting fails.

title: Fit Univariate Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model
text: Fits univariate regression model based selected approach.

title: Fit Univariate Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model
code: .fit_uni_model(data, outcome, exposure, approach)

title: Fit Univariate Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model
text: data `data.frame` complete observations outcome exposures. outcome string. Name outcome variable. exposure string. Name single predictor (exposure) variable. approach string specifying regression approach. One `"logit"`, `"log-binomial"`, `"poisson"`, `"linear"`, `"robpoisson"`.

title: Fit Univariate Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model
text: fitted model object (`glm`, `lm`, `riskratio`) `NULL` fitting fails.

title: Fit Univariate Negative Binomial Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model_nbin

title: Fit Univariate Negative Binomial Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model_nbin
code: .fit_uni_model_nbin(data, outcome, exposure)

title: Fit Univariate Negative Binomial Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model_nbin
text: data `data.frame` complete observations outcome exposures. outcome string. Name count outcome variable. exposure single predictor variable name.

title: Fit Univariate Negative Binomial Regression Model (Internal) — .fit_uni_model_nbin
text: fitted model object (class `negbin`) `NULL` model fitting fails data insufficient.

what: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar to reg check in stata Performs diagnostic tests for linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test for heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test for normality of residuals - RESET test for model specification - Cook's Distance for influential points — .reg_check_linear
title: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar to reg check in stata Performs diagnostic tests for linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test for heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test for normality of residuals - RESET test for model specification - Cook's Distance for influential points — .reg_check_linear
text: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar reg check stata Performs diagnostic tests linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test normality residuals - RESET test model specification - Cook's Distance influential points

title: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar to reg check in stata Performs diagnostic tests for linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test for heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test for normality of residuals - RESET test for model specification - Cook's Distance for influential points — .reg_check_linear
code: .reg_check_linear(model, exposure)

title: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar to reg check in stata Performs diagnostic tests for linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test for heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test for normality of residuals - RESET test for model specification - Cook's Distance for influential points — .reg_check_linear
text: model fitted linear model (`lm` object). exposure Character string giving name exposure variable (labeling).

title: Linear Regression Diagnostic Checks (Internal) similar to reg check in stata Performs diagnostic tests for linear regression models: - Breusch-Pagan test for heteroskedasticity - Shapiro-Wilk test for normality of residuals - RESET test for model specification - Cook's Distance for influential points — .reg_check_linear
text: data frame one row per diagnostic test, including: Exposure Name exposure variable. Test Diagnostic test name. Statistic Test statistic summary (e.g., p-values). Interpretation Plain-language result interpretation.

title: Validate regression approach by context — .validate_approach
text: Ensures valid modeling approaches used function context

title: Validate regression approach by context — .validate_approach
code: .validate_approach(approach, context = NULL)

title: Validate regression approach by context — .validate_approach
text: approach character string specifying regression method. context name function using approach (e.g., "uni_reg").

title: Validate regression approach by context — .validate_approach
text: Stops informative error approach allowed.

what: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
text: function evaluates whether one variables confounders exposure outcome comparing crude adjusted effect estimates. variable considered confounder inclusion model changes effect size specified threshold (default: 10

title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
code: identify_confounder(   data,   outcome,   exposure,   potential_confounder,   approach = "logit",   threshold = 10 )

title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome name outcome variable exposure name main exposure variable test. potential_confounder variable test potential confounder approach regression modeling approach. One : "logit" (logistic), "log-binomial", "poisson", "negbin" (negative binomial), "robpoisson", "linear". threshold value specifying percent change estimate absolute percent change crude adjusted estimate exceeds threshold, variable flagged confounder.

title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
text: `tibble` summarizing: Crude effect estimate (e.g., , RR, IRR, Beta) Adjusted effect estimate (including potential confounder) Percent change estimate Confounder flag (TRUE/FALSE)

title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
text: Supports multiple regression approaches including logistic, log-binomial, Poisson, negative binomial, robust Poisson, linear regression.

title: Identify Confounders Using the Change-in-Estimate Method — identify_confounder
code: data <- data_PimaIndiansDiabetes identify_confounder(   data = data,   outcome = "glucose",   exposure = "insulin",   potential_confounder = "age_cat",   approach = "linear" ) #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Crude Estimate:               0.151  #> Adjusted Estimate:            NA  #> Percent Change from Crude:    NA % #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Confounding:                  NA  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Notes: #> * Confounding is suggested if percent change >= 10 %. #> * This method does not assess effect modification. #> * Use DAGs or domain knowledge to support confounder identification.

what: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
title: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
text: function fits two models—one one without interaction term exposure potential effect modifier— compares using either likelihood ratio test (LRT) Wald test. useful assessing whether statistical evidence interaction (effect modification).

title: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
code: interaction_models(   data,   outcome,   exposure,   covariates = NULL,   effect_modifier,   approach = "logit",   test = c("LRT", "Wald"),   verbose = TRUE )

title: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
text: data data frame containing required variables. outcome name outcome variable exposure name main exposure variable. covariates character vector additional covariates adjust effect_modifier name variable test interaction approach regression modeling approach use. One : "logit", "log-binomial", "poisson", "robpoisson", "negbin", "linear". test Type statistical test model comparison. Either: "LRT" (likelihood ratio test, default) "Wald". verbose Logical; TRUE, prints basic interpretation whether interaction likely present (default = FALSE).

title: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
text: list following elements: model_no_interaction: model without interaction term. model_with_interaction: model interaction term. p_value: p-value interaction (based selected test). interpretation: brief text interpretation   verbose = TRUE.

title: Compare Models With and Without Interaction Term — interaction_models
code: data <- data_PimaIndiansDiabetes

what: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
title: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
text: Modify Regression Table Labels Layout Allows customization publication ready tables Designed use tables generated regression functions

title: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
code: modify_table(   gt_table,   variable_labels = NULL,   level_labels = NULL,   header_labels = NULL,   caption = NULL,   bold_labels = FALSE,   bold_levels = FALSE,   remove_N = FALSE,   remove_N_obs = FALSE,   remove_abbreviations = FALSE,   caveat = NULL )

title: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
text: gt_table `gtsummary` table object variable_labels named vector relabel variable names. level_labels named vector relabel levels variables. header_labels named vector relabel table column headers. Names must match internal column names (e.g., `"estimate"`, `"p.value"`). caption character string add caption (table title). bold_labels Logical. `TRUE`, variable labels bolded. bold_levels Logical. `TRUE`, factor level labels bolded. remove_N Logical. `TRUE`, hides sample size column (`N`) univariate regression tables (`uni_reg`, `uni_reg_nbin`). Ignored multivariate tables warning. remove_N_obs Logical. `TRUE`, removes source note showing N_obs sample size multivariate regression tables  (`multi_reg`, `multi_reg_nbin`). Ignored univariate tables warning. remove_abbreviations Logical. `TRUE`, removes abbreviations showing expansions effect size confidence interval  regression table outputs caveat character string add source note table (e.g., "N may vary due missing data."). always applied regardless table type.

title: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
text: customized `gtsummary` table object modified labels, layout, options.

title: Modify Regression Table Labels and Layout Allows customization of publication ready tables Designed for use with tables generated by regression functions — modify_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(gtregression) tbl_custom <- modify_table(   uni_rr,   variable_labels = c(age_cat = "Age", bmi = "BMI"),   level_labels = list(age_cat = c(`Young` = "Young Adults",   `Old` = "Older Adults")),   header_labels = c(estimate = "**Risk Ratio**",   `p.value` = "***P*-value**"),   caption = "Table 1: Univariate Regression",   bold_labels = TRUE,   remove_N = TRUE,   caveat = "N may vary due to missing data." ) } # }

what: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
text: Fits multivariable regression models binary, count, continuous outcomes returns publication-ready summary table using `gtsummary`. Depending specified `approach`, function estimates adjusted Odds Ratios (), Risk Ratios (RR), Incidence Rate Ratios (IRR), Beta coefficients.

title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
code: multi_reg(data, outcome, exposures, approach = "logit")

title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
text: data data frame containing analysis variables. outcome name outcome variable. Must character string. exposures predictor variables included model. approach Modeling approach use. One : - `"logit"` logistic regression (), - `"log-binomial"` log-binomial regression (RR), - `"poisson"` Poisson regression (IRR), - `"robpoisson"` robust Poisson regression (RR), - `"linear"` linear regression (Beta coefficients).

title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
text: object class `multi_reg`, includes: - `gtsummary::tbl_regression` object adjusted effect estimates, - list fitted model(s) accessible via `$models`, - Tidy model summaries accessible via `$model_summaries`.

title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
text: $models List fitted model objects. $model_summaries tibble tidy regression   summaries model.

title: Multivariable Regression (Adjusted Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — multi_reg
code:
if (requireNamespace("mlbench", quietly = TRUE)) { data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench") pima <- dplyr::mutate(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, diabetes == "pos") model <- multi_reg( data = pima, outcome = "diabetes", exposures = c("age", "mass"), approach = "logit" ) print(model) } #>
#> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
CharacteristicAdjusted OR95% CIp-value
age1.051.03, 1.06<0.001
mass1.111.09, 1.14<0.001
Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, OR = Odds Ratio
N = 757 complete observations included in the multivariate model
#>

what: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
text: Performs multivariable negative binomial regression using specified exposures count outcome. Returns publication-ready regression table adjusted incidence rate ratios (IRRs) using `gtsummary`.

title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
code: multi_reg_nbin(data, outcome, exposures)

title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome name count outcome variable. exposures character vector specifying predictor (exposure)

title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
text: object class `multi_reg_nbin`, includes: - `gtsummary::tbl_regression` object exponentiated IRRs, - fitted model object accessible via `$models`, - tidy model summary via `$model_summaries`, - regression table via `$table`.

title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
text: $models Fitted negative binomial model object   (class `negbin`). $model_summaries Tidy summary table model estimates. $table Formatted `gtsummary` regression table    adjusted IRRs.

title: Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression (Adjusted IRRs) — multi_reg_nbin
code: if (requireNamespace("MASS", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(Pima.tr, package = "MASS")   multi_nb <- multi_reg_nbin(     data = Pima.tr,     outcome = "glu",     exposures = c("age", "bmi")   )   multi_nb$table }     Characteristic       Adjusted IRR       95% CI       p-value     age 1.01 1.00, 1.01 <0.001bmi 1.01 1.00, 1.01 0.004Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, IRR = Incidence Rate Ratio     N = 200 complete observations included in the multivariate model

what: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
title: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
text: Creates forest plot `gtsummary` object. Supports univariate multivariable models hierarchical labels categorical variables. Designed work seamlessly outputs functions like `uni_reg()` `multi_reg()`.

title: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
code: plot_reg(   tbl,   title = NULL,   ref_line = 1,   order_y = NULL,   log_x = FALSE,   xlim = NULL,   breaks = NULL,   point_color = "#1F77B4",   errorbar_color = "#4C4C4C",   base_size = 14,   show_ref = TRUE )

title: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
text: tbl `gtsummary` object regression functions title Optional plot title (character). ref_line Numeric value reference line (default = 1). order_y Optional character vector customise y-axis order log_x Logical. `TRUE`, uses logarithmic x-axis (default = FALSE). xlim Optional numeric vector specifying x-axis limits breaks Optional numeric vector x-axis tick breaks. point_color Color points (default automatic). errorbar_color Color error bars (default automatic). base_size Base font size text elements. show_ref Logical. `TRUE`, includes reference plot.

title: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
text: `ggplot2` object representing forest plot.

title: Visualize a Regression Model as a Forest Plot — plot_reg
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- data_PimaIndiansDiabetes uni_model <- uni_reg(data, "glucose", "bmi", approach = "linear") plot_reg(uni_model) } # }

what: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
title: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
text: Generates side--side plots compare univariate & multivariable results

title: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
code: plot_reg_combine(   tbl_uni,   tbl_multi,   title_uni = NULL,   title_multi = NULL,   ref_line = 1,   order_y = NULL,   log_x = FALSE,   point_color = "#1F77B4",   errorbar_color = "#4C4C4C",   base_size = 14,   show_ref = TRUE,   xlim_uni = NULL,   breaks_uni = NULL,   xlim_multi = NULL,   breaks_multi = NULL )

title: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
text: tbl_uni `gtsummary` object `uni_reg()` etc., tbl_multi `gtsummary` object `multi_reg()`. title_uni Optional plot title univariate model title_multi Optional plot title multivariable mode ref_line Numeric value reference line (default = 1). order_y Optional character vector manually order y-axis labels. log_x Logical. `TRUE`, x-axis log-transformed (default = FALSE). point_color Optional color plot points. errorbar_color Optional color error bars. base_size Numeric. Base font size plot text elements. show_ref Logical. `TRUE`, includes reference categories xlim_uni Optional numeric vector set x-axis limits uni plot. breaks_uni Optional numeric vector set x-axis breaks uni plot. xlim_multi Optional numeric vector set x-axis limits multi plot breaks_multi Optional numeric vector set x-axis breaks- multi plot.

title: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
text: `ggplot2` object two forest plots displayed side--side.

title: Visualize Univariate and Multivariate Regression Side-by-Side — plot_reg_combine
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- data_PimaIndiansDiabetes uni_model <- uni_reg(data, "glucose", "bmi", approach = "linear") multi_model <- multi_reg(data, "glucose", c("bmi", "age"), approach = "linear") plot_reg_combine(tbl_uni = uni_model, tbl_multi = multi_model) } # }

what: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
title: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
text: Saves collection `gtsummary` tables `ggplot2` plots (`.docx`)

title: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
code: save_docx(tables = NULL, plots = NULL, filename = "report.docx", titles = NULL)

title: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
text: tables list `gtsummary` tables. plots list `ggplot2` plot objects. filename File name output (without `.docx` extension). titles Optional. character vector titles

title: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
text: Word document saved wd. object returned

title: Save Multiple Tables and Plots to a Word Document — save_docx
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(gtsummary) library(ggplot2)  # Create table and plot tbl <- tbl_regression(glm(mpg ~ hp + wt, data = mtcars)) p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point()  # Save both into a single Word document save_docx(   tables = list(tbl),   plots = list(p),   filename = "report.docx",   titles = c("Table 1: Regression", "Figure 1: Scatterplot") ) } # }

title: Save a Single Plot — save_plot
text: Saves `ggplot2` plot file PNG, PDF, JPG format.

title: Save a Single Plot — save_plot
code: save_plot(   plot,   filename = "plot",   format = c("png", "pdf", "jpg"),   width = 8,   height = 6,   dpi = 300 )

title: Save a Single Plot — save_plot
text: plot `ggplot2` object. filename Name file save, without extension. format Output format. One `"png"`, `"pdf"`, `"jpg"`. width Width saved plot inches. height Height saved plot inches. dpi Resolution plot dots per inch (default 300).

title: Save a Single Plot — save_plot
text: Saves file current working directory.

title: Save a Single Plot — save_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() save_plot(p, filename = "scatterplot", format = "png", width = 6, height = 4) } # }

what: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
title: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
text: Saves `gtsummary` table Word, PDF, HTML file

title: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
code: save_table(tbl, filename = "table", format = c("docx", "pdf", "html"))

title: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
text: tbl `gtsummary` object (e.g.,`tbl_regression()`, `tbl_summary()`). filename File name save output. Extension optional format Output format. One `"docx"`, `"pdf"`, `"html"`.

title: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
text: Saves file wd. return object.

title: Save a Single Regression Table — save_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ model <- glm(mpg ~ hp + wt, data = mtcars) tbl <- gtsummary::tbl_regression(model) save_table(tbl, filename = "regression_table", format = "docx") } # }

what: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
title: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
text: Performs stepwise model selection using forward, backward, directions  across different regression approaches. Returns summary table evaluation metrics (AIC, BIC, log-likelihood, deviance) best model.

title: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
code: select_models(   data,   outcome,   exposures,   approach = "logit",   direction = "forward" )

title: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
text: data data frame containing outcome predictor variables. outcome character string indicating outcome variable. exposures vector predictor variables consider model. approach Regression method. One : "logit", "log-binomial", "poisson", "robpoisson", "negbin", "linear". direction Stepwise selection direction. One : "forward" (default), "backward", "".

title: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
text: list following components: results_table: tibble summarising tested model's metric   (AIC, BIC, deviance, log-likelihood, adjusted R² applicable). best_model: best-fitting model object based low AIC. all_models: named list fitted models.

title: Stepwise Model Selection with Evaluation Metrics — select_models
code: data <- data_PimaIndiansDiabetes stepwise <- select_models(   data = data,   outcome = "glucose",   exposures = c("age", "pregnant", "mass"),   approach = "linear",   direction = "forward" ) summary(stepwise) #>               Length Class  Mode #> results_table  8     tbl_df list #> best_model    13     lm     list #> all_models     3     -none- list stepwise$results_table #> # A tibble: 3 × 8 #>   model_id formula              n_predictors   AIC   BIC logLik deviance adj_r2 #>      <dbl> <chr>                       <int> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1        1 glucose ~ 1                     1 7386. 7395. -3691.  710508. 0      #> 2        2 glucose ~ mass                  2 7242. 7256. -3618.  665157. 0.0529 #> 3        3 glucose ~ mass + age            2 7190. 7209. -3591.  618925. 0.118  stepwise$best_model #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = glucose ~ mass + age, data = data) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)         mass          age   #>     67.0644       1.0029       0.6702   #>

what: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
title: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
text: Performs multivariable negative binomial regression stratified specified variable. Observations missing values stratifier excluded.

title: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
code: stratified_multi_nbin(data, outcome, exposures, stratifier)

title: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome character string specifying count outcome variable. exposures character vector predictor (exposure) variables. stratifier character string specifying stratifier

title: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
text: object class `stratified_multi_reg_nbin` following: $table `gtsummary::tbl_merge` stratified model tables. $models named list `glm.nb` model objects per stratum. $model_summaries list tidy model summaries.

title: Stratified Multivariable Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_multi_nbin
text: Use `object$table`, `object$models`, `object$model_summaries`, `object$reg_check` extract components.

what: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
text: Performs multivariable regression multiple exposures binary, count, continuous outcome, stratified specified variable. NA values stratifier excluded analysis.

title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
code: stratified_multi_reg(data, outcome, exposures, stratifier, approach = "logit")

title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome name outcome variable. exposures vector specifying predictor (exposure) variables. stratifier character string specifying stratifying variable. approach Modeling approach use. One : `"logit"` (Adjusted Odds Ratios), `"log-binomial"` (Adjusted Risk Ratios), `"poisson"` (Adjusted IRRs), `"robpoisson"` (Robust RRs), `"linear"` (Beta coefficients).

title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
text: object class `stratified_multi_reg`, includes: - `table`: `gtsummary::tbl_stack` object regression tables stratum, - `models`: named list model objects stratum, - `model_summaries`: list tidy model summaries, - `reg_check`: Diagnostics results (available model type).

title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
text: $table Stacked table stratified regression outputs. $models Named list fitted models per stratum. $model_summaries Tidy summaries model. $reg_check Regression diagnostic checks (applicable).

title: Stratified Multivariable Regression (Adjusted OR, RR, IRR, or Beta) — stratified_multi_reg
code: if (requireNamespace("mlbench", quietly = TRUE) &&   requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench")   pima <- dplyr::mutate(     PimaIndiansDiabetes2,     diabetes = ifelse(diabetes == "pos", 1, 0),     glucose_cat = dplyr::case_when(       glucose < 140 ~ "Normal",       glucose >= 140 ~ "High"     )   )   stratified_multi <- stratified_multi_reg(     data = pima,     outcome = "diabetes",     exposures = c("age", "mass"),     stratifier = "glucose_cat",     approach = "logit"   )   stratified_multi$table } #> Running stratified multivariable regression by: glucose_cat #>   > Stratum: glucose_cat = High #>   > Stratum: glucose_cat = Normal     Characteristic                glucose_cat = High                       glucose_cat = Normal            Adjusted OR       95% CI       p-value       Adjusted OR       95% CI       p-value     age 1.02 1.00, 1.05 0.12 1.04 1.02, 1.06 <0.001mass 1.07 1.02, 1.13 0.005 1.10 1.07, 1.14 <0.001Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, OR = Odds Ratio     glucose_cat = High: N = 197 complete observations included in the multivariate modelglucose_cat = Normal: N = 555 complete observations included in the multivariate model

what: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
text: Performs univariate negative binomial regression stratified specified variable. Missing values stratifier excluded.

title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
code: stratified_uni_nbin(data, outcome, exposures, stratifier)

title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome character string specifying count outcome variable. exposures character vector specifying exposure variables. stratifier character string specifying stratifying variable.

title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
text: object class `stratified_uni_reg_nbin` following: $table `gtsummary::tbl_merge` tables stratum. $models named list fitted negbin models per stratum. $model_summaries list tidy summaries model.

title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
text: Use `object$table`, `object$models`, `object$model_summaries` extract components.

title: Stratified Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — stratified_uni_nbin
code: if (requireNamespace("MASS", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(Pima.tr, package = "MASS")   Pima.tr$strata <- ifelse(Pima.tr$bmi > 30, "High", "Normal")   strat_uni_nb <- stratified_uni_nbin(     data = Pima.tr,     outcome = "glu",     exposures = c("age", "ped"),     stratifier = "strata"   )   strat_uni_nb$table } #> Running stratified univariate negative binomial regression by: strata #>   > Stratum: strata = High #>   > Stratum: strata = Normal     Characteristic                strata = High                       strata = Normal            N       IRR       95% CI       p-value       N       IRR       95% CI       p-value     age 132 1.01 1.00, 1.01 <0.001 68 1.01 1.00, 1.01 0.004ped 132 1.06 0.93, 1.22 0.4 68 0.98 0.81, 1.19 0.8Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, IRR = Incidence Rate Ratio

what: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
text: Performs univariate regression exposure binary, count, continuous outcome, stratified specified variable. Produces stacked `gtsummary` table one column per stratum, along underlying models diagnostics.

title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
code: stratified_uni_reg(data, outcome, exposures, stratifier, approach = "logit")

title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome name outcome variable. exposures vector specifying predictor (exposure) variables. stratifier character string specifying stratifier approach Modeling approach use. One : `"logit"` (Odds Ratios), `"log-binomial"` (Risk Ratios), `"poisson"` (Incidence Rate Ratios), `"robpoisson"` (Robust RR),  `"linear"` (Beta coefficients).

title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
text: object class `stratified_uni_reg`, includes: - `table`: `gtsummary::tbl_stack` object stratified results, - `models`: list fitted models stratum, - `model_summaries`: tidy list model summaries, - `reg_check`: tibble regression diagnostics (available).

title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
text: $table Stacked stratified regression table. $models List fitted model objects stratum. $model_summaries List tidy model summaries. $reg_check Diagnostic check results (applicable).

title: Performs univariate regression for each exposure on a binary, count, or continuous outcome, stratified by a specified variable. Produces a stacked `gtsummary` table with one column per stratum, along with underlying models and diagnostics. — stratified_uni_reg
code: if (requireNamespace("mlbench", quietly = TRUE) &&   requireNamespace("dplyr", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench")   pima <- dplyr::mutate(     PimaIndiansDiabetes2,     diabetes = ifelse(diabetes == "pos", 1, 0),     glucose_cat = dplyr::case_when(       glucose < 140 ~ "Normal",       glucose >= 140 ~ "High"     )   )   stratified_uni <- stratified_uni_reg(     data = pima,     outcome = "diabetes",     exposures = c("age", "mass"),     stratifier = "glucose_cat",     approach = "logit"   )   stratified_uni$table } #> Running stratified univariate regression by: glucose_cat #>   > Stratum: glucose_cat = High #>   > Stratum: glucose_cat = Normal     Characteristic                glucose_cat = High                       glucose_cat = Normal            N       OR       95% CI       p-value       N       OR       95% CI       p-value     age 197 1.01 0.99, 1.04 0.3 566 1.04 1.02, 1.06 <0.001mass 197 1.07 1.02, 1.12 0.010 555 1.10 1.07, 1.14 <0.001Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, OR = Odds Ratio

what: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
title: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
text: Performs univariate regression exposure binary, continuous, count outcome. Depending `approach`, returns either Odds Ratios (), Risk Ratios (RR), Incidence Rate Ratios (IRR).

title: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
code: uni_reg(data, outcome, exposures, approach = "logit")

title: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome outcome variable (binary, continuous, count). exposures vector predictor variables. approach Modeling approach use. One : `"logit"` (), `"log-binomial"` (RR), `"poisson"` (IRR), `"robpoisson"` (RR), `"linear"` (Beta coefficients)

title: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
text: function requires following packages: `dplyr`, `purrr`, `gtsummary`, `risks`. #' @return list class `uni_reg` `gtsummary::tbl_stack`, including: publication-ready regression table (`tbl_stack`) Accessor elements: `$models`: Fitted regression models exposure `$model_summaries`: Tidy model summaries `$reg_check`: Diagnostics (linear regression)

title: Univariate regression (Odds, Risk, or Rate Ratios) — uni_reg
code: data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench") library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union pima <- PimaIndiansDiabetes2 |>   dplyr::mutate(diabetes = ifelse(diabetes == "pos", 1, 0)) uni_reg(pima, outcome = "diabetes", exposures = "age", approach = "logit")     Characteristic       N       OR       95% CI       p-value     age 768 1.04 1.03, 1.06 <0.001Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, OR = Odds Ratio

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
text: Performs univariate negative binomial regression specified exposure count outcome. Returns publication-ready stacked regression table using `gtsummary`, incidence rate ratios (IRRs) confidence intervals.

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
code: uni_reg_nbin(data, outcome, exposures)

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
text: data data frame containing variables. outcome name count outcome variable (character). exposures character vector predictor variables.

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
text: object class `uni_reg_nbin`, includes: - `gtsummary::tbl_stack` object exponentiated IRRs, - list model objects accessible via `$models`, - Tidy summaries models via `$model_summaries`, - stacked table via `$table`.

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
text: $models List fitted negative binomial model objects. $model_summaries tibble tidy model summaries. $table `gtsummary::tbl_stack` object unadjusted IRRs.

title: Univariate Negative Binomial Regression — uni_reg_nbin
code: if (requireNamespace("mlbench", quietly = TRUE)) {   data(PimaIndiansDiabetes2, package = "mlbench")   pima <- dplyr::mutate(     PimaIndiansDiabetes2,     pregnant = as.integer(pregnant)   )   reg <- uni_reg_nbin(     data = pima,     outcome = "pregnant",     exposures = c("age", "mass")   )   reg$table }     Characteristic       N       IRR       95% CI       p-value     age 768 1.04 1.04, 1.05 <0.001mass 757 1.00 0.99, 1.01 0.5Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, IRR = Incidence Rate Ratio

title: gtregression 1.0.0
text: Initial release gtregression. Added support logit, log-binomial, linear, Poisson, roboisson, negative binomial models. Added functions confounder identification, model selection, diagnostics, plotting, saving output. Added forest plot functions (plot_reg, plot_reg_combine) Improved documentation homepage
